title: 104_hr1004
content: The "Communications Decency Act of 1995" may be cited as the Act. It addresses obscene or harassing use of telecommunications facilities under the Communications Act of 1934. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to include broader definitions of offenses related to telecommunications devices, including making comments, requests, suggestions, proposals, images, or other communications without disclosure. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to include broader definitions of offenses related to telecommunications devices, such as making repeated calls or initiating communication solely to harass someone. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to include broader definitions of offenses related to telecommunications devices, such as making repeated calls or initiating communication solely to harass someone. The amendments include changes to terminology like replacing "telephone" with "telecommunications device" and updating language regarding making calls or transmissions. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to include broader definitions of offenses related to telecommunications devices, such as making repeated calls or initiating communication solely to harass someone. Penalties for violations are increased to $100,000 and 2 years imprisonment. The section heading is updated to reflect the changes in terminology from "telephone" to "telecommunications device." SEC. 3. OBSCENE PROGRAMMING ON CABLE TELEVISION and SEC. 4. BROADCASTING OBSCENE LANGUAGE ON RADIO are amended to increase penalties from $10,000 to $100,000. SEC. 5. addresses interception and disclosure of electronic communications. SEC. 5 amends Section 2511 of title 18, United States Code to include digital communication. SEC. 6 prohibits billing for toll-free telephone calls. SEC. 6 prohibits billing for toll-free telephone calls and adds a prohibition on charging the calling party for connecting to a pay-per-call service. SEC. 7 addresses the scrambling of cable channels for nonsubscribers. SEC. 640 requires cable operators to fully scramble or block unsuitable programming for children from nonsubscribers. SEC. 8 allows cable operators to refuse to carry certain programs. SEC. 8 allows cable operators to refuse to transmit public access or leased access programs containing obscenity, indecency, or nudity.
